description: The user uploads a contract, the assistant extracts the limitation‑of‑liability clause, retrieves California litigation precedents for that clause, and presents the most relevant cases.

messages.content: You are LexRiskScorer, an AI‑powered legal risk scoring assistant. Use the provided tools to upload contracts, extract clauses, retrieve similar litigation outcomes, calculate risk scores, suggest mitigations, and generate reports. Always keep the user informed of each step.
I need examples of litigation precedents involving a broad limitation‑of‑liability clause in a California contract.
Sure, I can help with that. Please provide the contract file (PDF or DOCX) so I can locate the exact limitation‑of‑liability clause you’re using.
Contract uploaded successfully (ID: contract_abc123). I will now extract the "Limitation of Liability" clause.

{"clause_text": "Limitation of Liability. Neither party shall be liable for any indirect, special, consequential or punitive damages arising out of this Agreement, regardless of the cause of action, up to a maximum liability of $1,000,000."}
Clause extracted. I will now search our litigation database for California cases that involved similarly broad limitation‑of‑liability language.

Here are the most relevant California cases that dealt with limitation‑of‑liability clauses similar to the one in your contract:

1. **ABC Tech v. XYZ Solutions** – *Dismissed for overbroad indemnity* (CA). The court ruled the clause unenforceable because it attempted to waive liability for gross negligence and willful misconduct. No monetary impact. [Read case](https://publiccases.example.com/abc-tech-v-xyz)

2. **Global Corp v. Regional Ltd.** – *Settlement* (CA). The parties settled for $750,000 after the plaintiff successfully argued the clause was ambiguous and overly broad. [Read case](https://publiccases.example.com/global-corp-v-regional)

3. **BlueSky Inc. v. GreenFields LLC** – *Partial summary judgment* (CA). The court upheld the limitation up to $500,000 but invalidated the portion that attempted to limit liability for breach of confidentiality, resulting in a $300,000 exposure. [Read case](https://publiccases.example.com/bluesky-v-greenfields)

These precedents illustrate how California courts scrutinize broad limitation‑of‑liability language, especially when it tries to waive liability for negligence, misconduct, or confidentiality breaches.
